comments:
Build ID: M20060629-1905

Steps To Reproduce:
1. open the new class wizard in a project (I'm using managed make)
2. enter a name for your class
3. note that it says at the top "class name is empty" and doesn't enable the "finish" button, rendering the class wizard useless
4. the same problem seems to happen to the namespace field


More information:
Obviously, the class wizard is 100% useless if you can never make it do anything.  Of note: on my machine, typing in the class name and namespace fields is VERY slow (multiple seconds for a single character to appear in the box after being typed).  This seems to me to be likely related to whatever validation is going on (and failing).  I've used the built-in eclipse update utility to update everything, restarted eclipse a number of times, and even rebooted my computer - this problem persists.
Which version of Linux are you using?

I'm using Fedora Core 5.
uname -r: 2.6.18-1.2257.fc5

In the time since my initial posting, I've downloaded a fresh copy of eclipse and installed it; I still have the problem.  Since I've never had this problem before, it must have been introduced in a recent update.
Hmm I installed Fedora Core 5 and ran fresh copies of Eclipse 3.2.1 & CDT 3.1.1 on it and it works for me.

Hi there,

I am having the same problem, but I have a bit more more information. Whenever I open the 'New C++ Class' dialog and type characters into the 'Class Name:' field, each character I type results in two exceptions appearing in the PDE Runtime Error Log:

- java.lang.NullPointerException
- Unhandled event loop exception

I'll take a look and see what I can find. This might just be a corrupt index. Doing a "Rebuild Index" on the project should fix. But I'll see if there is something tempermental with the class wizard.

One thing I've noticed is that the NewClassWizard utils didn't acquire a read lock on the PDOM. I'll make this change but since I can't reproduce the error, I can't be sure if it fixes it.

Let me know if a rebuild index fixes the problem and I can look at it more then.
I switch to no index, click on ok. Switch back to fast index . it's has corrected the problem.
Yes, that points at a corrupt index. Switching indexers caused a reindex to happen. I'll move this off the 3.1.2 list for now.

(In reply to comment #9)
> Yes, that points at a corrupt index. Switching indexers caused a reindex to
> happen. I'll move this off the 3.1.2 list for now.

Doug, can we close this as FIXED?
I guess if no one has seen this in CDT 4.
